pageProps.contentHtml:
harmonic functions, residue theorem

Let a1,…,ana_1, \ldots, a_na1​,…,an​ be n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 distinct points in C\CC and let Ω=C∖{a1,…,an}\Omega = \C \setminus \set{a_1, \ldots, a_n}Ω=C∖{a1​,…,an​}. Let H(Ω)H\p{\Omega}H(Ω) be the vector space of real-valued harmonic functions on Ω\OmegaΩ and let R(Ω)⊆H(Ω)R\p{\Omega} \subseteq H\p{\Omega}R(Ω)⊆H(Ω) be the space of real parts of analytic functions on Ω\OmegaΩ. Prove the quotient space H(Ω)/R(Ω)H\p{\Omega}/R\p{\Omega}H(Ω)/R(Ω) has dimension nnn, find a basis for this space, and prove it is a basis.
Solution.

We claim that {u1,…,un}\set{u_1, \ldots, u_n}{u1​,…,un​}, where uk(z)=12πlog⁡ ∣z−ak∣u_k\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi}\log\,\abs{z - a_k}uk​(z)=2π1​log∣z−ak​∣, is a basis for H(Ω)/R(Ω)H\p{\Omega}/R\p{\Omega}H(Ω)/R(Ω). Pick {r1,…,rn}\set{r_1, \ldots, r_n}{r1​,…,rn​} small enough so that B(ak,rk)‾⊆Ω\cl{B\p{a_k, r_k}} \subseteq \OmegaB(ak​,rk​)​⊆Ω and are pairwise disjoint.

First, we need to show that they are linearly independent. For each uku_kuk​, consider its conjugate differential ∗duk=−(uk)y dx+(uk)x dy{}^*\diff{u_k} = -\p{u_k}_y \,\diff{x} + \p{u_k}_x \,\diff{y}∗duk​=−(uk​)y​dx+(uk​)x​dy. Now suppose we have coefficients c1,…,cnc_1, \ldots, c_nc1​,…,cn​ such that ∑k=1nckuk=0\sum_{k=1}^n c_k u_k = 0∑k=1n​ck​uk​=0. Taking conjugate differentials, we see

∑k=1nck∗duk=0  ⟹  0=∫∂B(aj,rj)∑k=1nck∗duk=∑k=1nckδkj=cj\sum_{k=1}^n c_k {}^*\diff{u_k} = 0 \implies 0 = \int_{\partial B\p{a_j,r_j}} \sum_{k=1}^n c_k {}^*\diff{u_k} = \sum_{k=1}^n c_k \delta_{kj} = c_jk=1∑n​ck​∗duk​=0⟹0=∫∂B(aj​,rj​)​k=1∑n​ck​∗duk​=k=1∑n​ck​δkj​=cj​

for all jjj by direct calculation, so all the coefficients are zero, which means that the uku_kuk​ are linearly independent.

Let u ⁣:Ω→R\func{u}{\Omega}{\R}u:Ω→R be harmonic and define f=ux−iuyf = u_x - iu_yf=ux​−iuy​, which is holomorphic on Ω\OmegaΩ since uuu is C2C^2C2 and satisfies the Cauchy-Riemann equations. If fff had an antiderivative F=U+iVF = U + iVF=U+iV, then by the Cauchy-Riemann equations again,

ux−iuy=f=F′=Ux−iVy  ⟹  u=U+C,u_x - iu_y = f = F' = U_x - iV_y \implies u = U + C,ux​−iuy​=f=F′=Ux​−iVy​⟹u=U+C,

where CCC is some constant, which would mean that u=Re⁡fu = \Re{f}u=Ref. But this may not be the case since Ω\OmegaΩ is simply connected. To ensure that a holomorphic ggg has an antiderivative, it suffices to have ∫γg(z) dz=0\int_\gamma g\p{z} \,\diff{z} = 0∫γ​g(z)dz=0 for any closed γ\gammaγ in Ω\OmegaΩ.

For each kkk, let ck=Res⁡(f;ak)c_k = \Res{f}{a_k}ck​=Res(f;ak​). Then by the residue theorem,

∫γf(z)−∑k=1nckz−ak dz=0\int_\gamma f\p{z} - \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{c_k}{z - a_k} \,\diff{z} = 0∫γ​f(z)−k=1∑n​z−ak​ck​​dz=0

for any closed curve γ\gammaγ in Ω\OmegaΩ. Thus, g(z)=f(z)−∑k=1nckz−akg\p{z} = f\p{z} - \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{c_k}{z - a_k}g(z)=f(z)−∑k=1n​z−ak​ck​​ is holomorphic in Ω\OmegaΩ with integral zero around any closed curve, so it has a primitive GGG on Ω\OmegaΩ, by Morera's theorem.

If we set u~(z)=u(z)+∑k=1ncklog⁡ ∣z−ak∣\tilde{u}\p{z} = u\p{z} + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k\log\,\abs{z - a_k}u~(z)=u(z)+∑k=1n​ck​log∣z−ak​∣, then

u~x(z)−iu~y(z)=ux(z)−iuy(z)+∑k=1nck(Re⁡(z−ak)∣z−ak∣2−iIm⁡(z−ak)∣z−ak∣2)=f(z)+∑k=1nckz−ak‾∣z−ak∣2=f(z)+∑k=1nckz−ak.\begin{aligned} \tilde{u}_x\p{z} - i\tilde{u}_y\p{z} &= u_x\p{z} - iu_y\p{z} + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k\p{\frac{\Re\p{z - a_k}}{\abs{z - a_k}^2} - \frac{i\Im\p{z - a_k}}{\abs{z - a_k}^2}} \\ &= f\p{z} + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k\frac{\conj{z - a_k}}{\abs{z - a_k}^2} \\ &= f\p{z} + \sum_{k=1}^n \frac{c_k}{z - a_k}. \end{aligned}u~x​(z)−iu~y​(z)​=ux​(z)−iuy​(z)+k=1∑n​ck​(∣z−ak​∣2Re(z−ak​)​−∣z−ak​∣2iIm(z−ak​)​)=f(z)+k=1∑n​ck​∣z−ak​∣2z−ak​​​=f(z)+k=1∑n​z−ak​ck​​.​

Hence, by our argument above, we see that u~\tilde{u}u~ is the real part of a harmonic function GGG on all of Ω\OmegaΩ, and so

u(z)+∑k=1ncklog⁡ ∣z−ak∣=Re⁡G(z)∈R(Ω).u\p{z} + \sum_{k=1}^n c_k\log\,\abs{z - a_k} = \Re{G\p{z}} \in R\p{\Omega}.u(z)+k=1∑n​ck​log∣z−ak​∣=ReG(z)∈R(Ω).

In particular, ckc_kck​ is real, so the uku_kuk​ span and this completes the proof.
